title: Has Brexit finally taken a bite out of British equities?
text:
It's not always a completely reliable indicator, but it's telling us to look out for a 0.1 per cent decline in British gross domestic product in the third quarter, following a 0.2 per cent shrinkage the previous quarter.

"September's decline is all the more ominous, being the result of an insidious weakening of demand over the past year rather than a sudden shock," said IHS Markit economist Chris Williamson.

Anecdotal evidence from the Bank of England's regional agents last month suggests that even consumption, which has kept the British economy afloat while business investment has stalled, may be slackening – despite rising wages and a jobless rate at a 40-year low.

It's little wonder that 'the markets truly lost their minds on Wednesday afternoon'

The markets were also rattled on Wednesday by the spectre of a trans-Atlantic tariff war, following a World Trade Organisation ruling in favour of US President Donald Trump, and of course the gyrations around whether UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson might land a Brexit deal, after he unveiled a new compromise proposal.

It's little wonder that "the markets truly lost their minds on Wednesday afternoon", as SpreadEx analyst Connor Campbell told Britain's Daily Telegraph.

Advertisement

One prop for British equities over the past year has been the FTSE 100 index's inverse correlation with the US dollar value of the pound. Every time there's been a bit of bad Brexit news, the skittish sterling drops. The currency has been at three-decade lows in the past month alone.

That's good news for Britain's listed behemoths, because collectively they make about 70 per cent of their profit in US dollars – so a falling pound means the sterling value of those profits goes up.

For some companies, of course, a falling pound means their supply chain imports become more expensive. But for others, their exports become more competitive. The profit factor seems to be key.

Since August, though, the inverse correlation has largely evaporated. The currency and stockmarket are moving in the same direction. It's not the first time this has happened, and what it signals is that investors are seeing signs of global stress all over the place.

You can also tell that from Britain's incredible bond market rally. The yield on Britain's 10-year government bond was just 0.44 per cent on Friday, and heading back down towards the record intraday low of 0.34 per cent posted last month.

The gloom that has settled over London markets has yet another side to it, too: it's not just that share prices are dropping – the amount of stock out there is ebbing.

Only 25 companies have floated on the London Stock Exchange so far this year, compared with 55 in 2018. More companies have delisted than listed. The net supply of equity is down 3 per cent this year as companies use cheap debt to buy back stock. That saps liquidity, so trading volumes are lower than in other major European markets.

These are not cheerful times.
description: All year, the FTSE 100 has remained impervious to Brexit, even as sterling twists on a dime. Is that changing?
